												Simple categorized review:Looks: The graphics haven't aged well (pixels), period. However, the art style is pretty nice and the spell animations are still quite beautiful. This game needs a remastered version! 5/10Story: I don't expect much of a story from this kind of game and I don't receive it, this is definitely what you neither should want the game to give to you. There is a story and the characters are likeable, at least the devs tried and got you some funny dialogues, always a goal in mind and, admittedly, even twists. It's better than in Torchlight 2 for example. 5/10Gameplay: Rather slow-paced hack'n'slay, compared to Diablo and Torchlight. The characters can be handled comfortably while sometimes the menus feel clumsy and outdated. Combat is fun, especially when you try out the many types of weapons and sorts of magic. The flow of the game is very good all in all, and with character progression and tons of loot you got to try out various play styles in a single play-through. 8/10 Character classes: Eight unique classes (two from the expansion) that feel and behave very distinctively. The war/combat-mage-hybrid is arguably the most fun character class in video game history when it comes to preset ones. Even then, there is a lot of customization to be done, skills to experiment with and tactics (especially in later new game plus). The balance has no flaws, in my experience, and you just wanna try out every character with every single play style. 10/10 Complexity: This game is deep, even deeper than your first play-throughs will make you think. New game plus holds a bunch of surprises later in the game and weapons and skill runes work together in a perfectly balanced and intriguing system, though the game is not hard to learn. You get into it and discover what it has to offer over time. Equip sets, customization, smart combining of equip and skills, varied enemies that need different approaches to be defeated, lots of secrets, skilling needs to be thought through thoroughly unless you wanna be smitten later in the game...The game is as complex as one would expect from a good RPG with focus on looting and leveling. 10/10World: The world is huge, diversified and has tons of secrets to show to an attentive adventurer. Monster types are far from being copy-paste and the art style is nice, as mentioned somewhere above. The problem is that it might become a repetitive experience in later play-throughs, without level-generation (- except from the highest difficulty mode that holds surprises, as I also said earlier on.) The settlements and castles deserve to be emphasised when I talk about the world, they are big, you can enter every building and they are full of stuff to do and see. Also, the world isn't vast at all. In Torchlight, for instance, I miss a huge map showing me the land that I shall care about and defend. 9/10Quests: Several quests are humorous and most of them are nicely written. Unfortunately, there is much stuff to be fetched, quests just lead to new areas and actually earn you very juicy rewards. There's quite a lot of quests to do, you can just do them on the run and have a good grin here and there when you track down someone's rabbit or speak to the "more simple" folks. Sometimes you make decisions. 7/10 in a game of this genre.Price: 10 $ or 2.50 $ on sale, pretty good deal.Replayability: I bet you won't discover everything there is to see in the game during your first play-through, or in the second, or third. At least you will want to try out different character classes and/or play styles. Expect the game to let you grind monsters for a couple of minutes here and there in new game plus, that can be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥if you're out for the best set equip. My 26 hours on Steam so far have been one play-through of the first campaign as an experienced player for nostalgic reasons (and trying to get the multiplayer to work), I could leave out a lot of stuff I didn't want to do for the tenth time. You can easily waste one hundred hours or more in this game - on one high-level character, that is. In later play-throughs, your equip and skills still really advance fast and give you the feel of becoming more and more powerful even after countless hours. 8/10Multiplayer: Online is dead. You can get it to work on LAN, however, up to four players if I recall it correctly. It then works absolutely fine, but it's not comfortable to set up. 1/10This game is the best of its genre, in my humble opinion, and a cult classic. You should play it. I will ignore my listing and give it a 10/10. Alright, there IS nostalgia involved. The metascore of 74 is reasonable. Give it some points up if you like this type of game and have fun in a game that is rather generic fantasy but excels by having great gameplay, complexity, character classes and an interesting open-world.

Score: 4/5; I recommend Sacred GoldPC; Win 8.1/10 64-bit; Sacred Gold v2.28completed; playing time: 147 hrsNote: If you experience problems with launching the game, go to the Sacred Gold main folder and find the Config.exe file. Run it, and check '32 Bit Color Depth.' Otherwise, the game will default to run in a 16-Bit-Color-Depth mode, and will probably freeze during loading, or crash. Sacred Gold v2.28 ran on my 64-bit Win 8.1 and 64-bit Win 10. I did not use compatibility mode at all. However, the game frequently crashed, so I had to quicksave quite often...Pros:+ Several characters to choose from, each with his/her distinctive advantages and drawbacks+ Replayability: characters start in different locations, have different backgrounds, and some different quests+ Numerous weapons, armour types, spells, items, and whatnot...+ Countless ways of developing your character during gameplay (by developing favourite skills, attributes, and combat arts, as well as modifying properties of your armour and weapons...)+ You can create combos+ In addition to the traditional swords and bows, there are firearms, muskets, and mines...+ There is a huge area to explore+ There are a great number of quests+ There are portals to facilitate travel between distant areasCons:- You only play as one character and can't create a permanent team. Sometimes an NPC may join you, but only temporarily, and you can neither control him/her nor have access to his/her inventory- Monster respawning can sometimes be a real pain in the neck... There's too many of them, too often...- The manual doesn't explain some aspects of the game well. Before you commit yourself to playing the game seriously, it's a good idea to read some extra information on how things work and how to develop your character on the Sacred wiki or find some good forums- Although the expansions - e.g. Sacred Underworld - introduce some interesting areas and quests, my overal impression was that they were worse thought out than the base game, with fewer good-quality quests or areas- A few quests broke becasue I accidentally started them "from the end," e.g. I found an item at the beginning before a quest was officially initialised; then, when the quest officially started and I was supposed to find the item, the game acted as if I had not found it, even though I already had it. The result was I couldn't finish the quest. However, I experienced very few quests like that (2 or perhaps 3...)- Remember that it's a 2005 game, so graphics are a little datedTo conclude, despite a few problems, it's a solid RPG worth getting and spending hours of your life playing it.

The Goodan unbelievably expansive, mostly open world that invites (and rewards) explorationan overwhelming amount of side questsa broad selection of playable characters/character classes, most of which offer a very distinct gameplay stylegorgeous and exceptionally detailed 2D backgroundsmountable horses and dwarves with guns... may not sound like anything special nowadays but back in my day it was the bomb, I tell ya!The Mehthe enemy selection/bestiary is rather bland; among the orcs, goblins, skeletons, dragons, spiders and, of course, humans, it's very rare to see any original enemy designs that you haven't seen many, many times before in other gameshaving to depend on dropped runes for the development of certain character abilities (like spells and special moves) might irritate some playersfinding a proper path to your targets on the map can sometimes be a bit more difficult than you'd expectthe portal system is unnecessarily restrictive; instead of town portal spells or scrolls that can be used at any time, teleportation is limited to a rather small number of portals you find all across the worldthis is more of a personal peeve, but I have never liked Sacred's main story; I think it's convoluted, draggy and rather boring, to be honestThe Uglyeven after all these years and with all patches installed, it's still possible to accidentally "break" certain quests or run into other minor bugs; frequent saving is advisedOverallWhat had been an absolutely amazing game that blew me away on release has held up admirably well over the years. Revisiting Sacred now after having played many of its modern competitors, I can say that its charm hasn't faded all that much. It might come off as a bit archaic initially, and it certainly has its quirks, but the world is still as massive and open and with all its countless side quests, secret caves and hidden treasures still as much fun to explore as I remembered. Ultimately, it's an incredibly addictive experience that'll keep completionists occupied for a very long time.

												I used to play Sacred roughly 10 years ago, before the expansion pack or Sacred Gold even came out. I was absolutely in love with it, and spent ages playing.The world of Ancaria always had a special place in my heart, so I decided to buy it again now and get back into it.It is true that getting it to start on Win 8.1 needs some arrangement, but this is fairly easy and you can do it in about 15 minutes maximum. (The description will be at the end of this review.)Now, on to the game:When looking at this game, we need to remember that it's a decade old. Even with that in mind, it is still much better than some RPGs that they put out today. There are 8 characters that you can use: Gladiator, Seraphim, Wood Elf, Battle Mage, Dark Elf, Vampiress and 2 that came with the Underworld expansion pack: Daemon and Dwarf.They each have pros and cons, and various combat arts. I have played with all of them, my personal favourite is the Dark Elf. (I prefer a more aggressive approach, no shields or two handed weapons, instead dual wielding+poison+fast attacks and traps) The map is huge and there are various kinds of lands to discover. (Tundra, desert, forest, underworld etc.) There are portals throughout the map to help you navigate more easily. There are tons of missions, named and unnamed sidequests which will occupy completionists for a long time. There are 5 difficulty levels (Bronze, Silver, Gold, Platinum, Niobium) The ones after silver only become available if you completed the game with the previous difficulty level. Advancing through the levels is necessary to face some real challanges, especially after you character is moderately leveled. The level cap is high (216, if I'm not mistaken) which means you can finetune your character as you wish. There is A LOT of loot, which is both a good and bad thing, as it can be overwhelming. I personally find having all these options very entertaining. There are set items, which if you wear together gives you really good bonuses. You get to have companions throughout the game (some immortal, some can die) and although they are not usually very strong, they still provide some support. You get to have a horse. I love games that gives me access to animals. (Also the Vampiress has a wolf and 2 bats) The horses have many different stats, the most important one being speed. Also, they can ram opponnents, which is useful especially if you are cornered while on horseback. Mounted combat is also an option. The characters have many spoken lines (Which is important in my opinion, for example Dragon Age: Origins -another game I really like- only has a couple of lines for the player controlled character, which get really boring to hear after a while "Can I get you a ladder, so you can get off my back?" Ugh.) There are TONS of pop culture references all over the world. I strongly recommend going grave-robbing. I have found 3 easter eggs by myself, and have read about others. So go exploring off the beaten track. The graphics are not the best, but considering how old the game is, I think it's pretty good. It's enjoyable.Overall: The game has interesting characters, huge world and mythology to discover, entertaining sidequests and storylines, good leveling mechanic and a lot of items to work with. I bought the game on a sale, but I still think it deserves the price it has now.Don't bother with any other Sacred games though, this one is the best. It all goes downhill from here.And here is the Windows 8.1 guide, ask if you need help with any of the steps.[/b] Update your graphic card drivers. Go to the Local Files of the game.(Right click the game in your library, click properties, then local files, then browse local files) There are 4 exe files there (config, game server, sacred, testapp). Change all of their settings so that they Run as Administrator always, and that they run in compatibility mode to Win 7. Click the "config.exe" and select "32-bit" and "video compatibility mode" They need to be checked. Enjoy the game!At first the game didn't run for me, and after that I had a graphics glitch. They were both fixed by these steps. There are some alternatives, ask if you wish.

The skill progression is simple yet diverse. The difference in skills and weapon use are well implemented; each character does feel unique. After finishing the main Ancaria campaign (which took ages since I felt I had to explore every inch of the map)  I must admit I didn't have much interest left to complete the Underworld campaign. To me it didn't feel as a real part of the game, both storywise and mapwise. But I do love the two extra characters, they are both my favorites to use. The demon's spells are interesting to play around with (more then just your common fire ball, you'll need the battle mage for that kind of work) and the dwarfs cannon gun and use of mines is quite satisfying.I like both Sacred and Sacred 2, but this is the game that will remain somewhat special to me. Even though by now I do understand what Diablo (1 & 2) is all about. So yes, of course I would recommend this game, play it!

												Whether singleplayer or with a group of friends, the old classic action rpg "Sacred Gold" is still lots of fun to play and still one of the best games of its genre. A huge vivid open world with lots of secrets to discover encourages traveling around and exploring, the character development is highly customizable with Combat Arts, self-selected Skills and Attributes. 												Creeping slowly and stealthily under the shadows of many contemporary upcoming games, Sacred never really generated much media hype prior to its release. What we have on our hands here, folks, is an action RPG coming from European development team at Ascaron Entertainment. Sacred uses the all too familiar design pattern long-establish by Blizzard's original Diablo. Basically, you have your average heroic fantasy tale, an ultimate evil unleashed by a dim-witted wizard, tons of monsters to mow down, and plenty of quests. More than anything else, this game focuses on character development and classic hack'n'slash gameplay. Still, you will find a bit more than that, so I'd advise you to read on.Coming up with a decent and innovative fantasy-style storytelling is definitely a difficult task these days. So, in all honesty, it would be deceitful to claim Sacred entails an exciting plot. Players are presented a rather basic and straightforward fantasy-themed storyline. The introduction sequence offers precious little to let you know exactly what the hell is going on. An evil wizard Shaddar summons an ancient evil and unleashes its devastating powers upon the Kingdom of Ancaria. Someone, naturally, has to put a stop to the chaos and disarray engulfing the unfortunate inhabitants of Ancaria. The first couple of quests won't reveal much of the story either, I'm afraid. In other words, it's actually pointless to seek some deeper meaning in the narrative since it remains somewhat scarce and incomplete throughout most of the game. But, believe it or not, the omission of a profound tale never appeared to bother me much during gameplay, given that all my attention was directed towards tearing monsters apart and leveling up my character. There were also some surprising moments of humor in the game. Opening graves and crypts, for instance, prompts amusing lines like, "In memory of all the monsters we have killed for experience points." The developers weren't too lazy to throw in a little something for Lord of the Rings fans. A certain stone ruin marked the following words: "Et Earello Endorenna utulien..." - for those of you who watched Return of the King, this is the beginning of the verse Aragorn sang at the end of the movie. This has nothing to do with the game, but it's still a nice and fun touch for all fantasy fans.At the beginning all you have to do is select one of the six available characters: a robust sandal-wearing Gladiator, a mysterious Battle mage, a sharp-witted and sinister Dark Elf, a light-hearted and valiant Wood Elf, a charismatic Seraphim, the tempting Vampiress, and the dark yet sultry Daemon. Each class concentrates on a unique combat style, either through magic and ranged attacks, or via melee attacks. The Gladiator, Battlemage, Dark Elf, and Wood Elf, offer a pretty standard range of abilities and skills we've already experienced in games like Neverwinter Nights, Diablo, Dungeon Siege, and so on. The Seraphim, Vampiress, and Daemon however, involve a few pleasing novelties combined with classic RPG character advancement. Although I was pleased with the statistics and overall appearance of all races, I somehow felt drawn towards the incredibly alluring Vampiress (what can I say, I just cannot contain my bloodlust anymore). Also, I got a bit fed up with spells, bows, and throwing knives, so this was just right... for me anyways. I'm sure all of you will find what you're looking for in other character classes, since they're all quite suitable for various styles of play.I think most RPG fans would be interested to know more about the regions of Sacred. The most commendable aspect of the game is the elimination of loading areas. Up to 70 % of the existing world map is accessible at the beginning of the campaign which comes as most appreciated gameplay element and allows players to choose multiple paths towards their primary destination. Another helpful addition is the world map which specifies exactly where your character can locate blacksmiths, merchants, etc. Additionally, each initiated quest is highlighted on the map, so there's no chance of getting lost even if you wanted to. There are many helpful additions to the gameplay. Each town, for example, features a chest in the center where low-level characters may lay down extra items which can be used later on during the game. If you find a ring, sword, or any other item you don't have enough experience to handle, just store it in one town and then pick it up in the next when you've leveled up the character. The journey between the towns should give you enough experience points so you can upgrade to the next level.Using the interface and inventory system should be a piece of cake for any gamer. Everything ran smoothly - upgrading general skills and specific combat abilities can be done quite easily, which also goes for exchanging items, upgrading weapons and armor, etc. As for the controls, about 80% of the game boils down to mouse-clicking (well, as you'd expect it from any Diablo style RPG). Apart from solving quests and slashing your way through swarms of goblins, orcs, gargoyles, thieves, assassins, and other baddies, the game will have you concentrating on using the most out of your character's capabilities. Beefing up armor and weapons is not the only thing you get to do. There's also an intuitively designed combat system at work, involving special moves, combos, and so on. Another appropriate moment in combat is the addition of horseback riding. Characters can purchase various breeds of horses which in turn helps them get around a lot quicker and gives them leverage during combat (provided they advanced the right skill).Visually, Sacred boasts a pleasing mix of 2D landscapes and fully modeled 3D characters and creatures. Even though the backdrops appear slightly outdated, especially when you zoom in, there's a pleasing amount of nicely drawn out details, such as trees, flowerbeds, bushes, and so on. Water surfaces look cool as well, and there's a whole choice of impressive and colorful spells to see. The camera allows you to zoom in on the action at any given time... even then the models appeared to show a meticulous approach in design and animation.The game's audio is quite good. Gamers will be immersed the whole time thanks to a jumble of realistic ambient noises and a range of sweet tunes. The voiceovers are okay, but there's really not much to involve you there I'm afraid. Everything else seems to be in place.If you decide to purchase this game, you won't regret it. There are no breakthroughs in terms of general design involved, but the open-ended gameplay and an admirably lengthy single-player campaign is enough to the fancy of any gamer. If we disregard the relatively weak plotline, this is really an enjoyable RPG experience with enough content and replayability to keep you occupied for days. Plus, this is one of those rare games I feel the incentive to play again after I'm done with the review...Recommended

												Good or bad? Well... both. It depends what you're looking for, though.Sacred's an old game. Like reaaaaally old. This brings with it some issues, unfortunately. The game itself is good, but the problems may be off-putting, so let's cover the technical issues first as they can be a dealbreaker for many people given what they are.First off, Sacred is hard-coded to be 1024x768 resolution; this means that, under normal circumstances, it will fill a 4:3 square on a widescreen monitor with large black boarders on the sides. There are a few workarounds, but the largely involve forcing it to stretch out the horizontal which makes everything look remarkably fat. This also means that the resolution can't normally be increased, and it won't get prettier or fit more stuff on the screen.The second major issue is that multiplayer is not naturally supported by steam, steam does not give out CD-keys when you buy the game, and it's irrelevant anyway because the servers for the game are down regardless. Hamachi, Gameranger, and most other options will flat out not work. Evolve, found at evolvehq.com, is the only one known to be able to run it (though some have reported that Hamachi can run it by changing some setting, but I don't speak german so have no idea what they changed). Evolve, however, can link itself to your steam account which... is a little unsettling. I didn't want to play sacred with friends quite THAT badly, so for me, it's stuck being a single player game.With that out of the way, if you're still interested in the game despite the technical difficulties and problems with it being ancient, let me state that the game itself is actually quite good with nice gameplay elements.Yes, it's old, and no, it won't be better than Path of Exile (which is free), but it has a certain charm and feel to it that makes it quite enjoyable. If you pick it up for $5 or under, it's probably worth the cost.A few major things:- There are quite a few different classes in the game (races, acutally...) and each get their own unique set of spells and melee attacks. They each play fairly differently, and have enough customization that each playthrough can potentially feel quite different even if playing the same class.- Skills are a bit odd in that you don't get access to all skills; each class begins with two skills and get a number of new skills unlocked at levels 1, 3, 6, 12, 20, 30 and 50. Interestingly enough, you just get to PICK a new skill at these levels (starting at 3) but have more options than you can choose from, so you customize your character each time you play. This means you can have a melee mage or a fire mage or a mage that specializes in a wide range of elements or one that spams out a small number of choice spells more often, one which autoattacks, or one which utilizes combo attacks as their primary method of damage, or even one which tanks (well, alright, not so much a tank mage =P ). The point is, you get some pretty good customization so two players can both pick to be the seraphim and play her entirely differently and not step on each other's toes. Assuming you get the multiplayer to work from the earlier issue. *Cough*- Mounts exist in the game and you can ride a horse. In fact, you can even learn mounted combat, use your horse to charge over people, or teach it to run faster. It's kind of a neat system, but isn't really explored too much, yet moreso than probably any other game of the genre.- Combat's pretty fluid, enemies have easy to see radial healthbars around their feet which indicate their relative difficulty, level and remaining health clearly. You can highlight items on the ground as well, which is handy. It's especially fun to bounce around the battlefield unleashing multihit combos and seeing your character do more than just overhand swing 5x in a row, but instead actually use a variety of strikes from different angles, and some will even perform acrobatic attacks, backflips, and so on.- The storyline's not the best the world has ever seen, but it's certainly not awful, and by diablo-style dungeon crawlers, it's way above average. There's actual reasons for going through the various quests, the world opens up in a reasonable manner as you complete them, bosses tend to make you want to slap them good and hard before you even fight them... generally it does a pretty good job at what it sets out to do.- The spells in the game are pretty varied, and the characters do distinctly feel different from one another, even if they have a similar role. Sure, the vampiress and daemon are both female melee characters, yet the vampiress gets to change between a knight form and vampire form, preferring physical or magical abilities in nature, can summon wolves and bats to help her, drain health and so on. The daemoness, in contrast, gets things like the ability to fly over terrain, attach elemental properties to her weapons, fling fireballs and enact creepy japanese hentai tentacle porn scenes with dead bodies. No, I am not making that up, and my nightmares would prefer that I were. Alright, they're not nightmares. >.>;;- Individual classes have different item slots available to them. Most of them tend to share similar gear, though there are a few bits which are very specific to certain classes, such as say... the iconic seraphim's wings.- Money MEANS something. Zoh. Mah. Gerd. Know how in Diablo 2 and such, you'd get huge stockpiles of gold that were worthless? Or most any other diablo-style game? Yeah, turns out that you can actually buy uniques and set items off of vendors. In fact, if you get the skill for it (sacrificing a combat skill...) some classes can even actually increase the quality of stuff that merchants will sell (along with reducing the cost of such, and increasing the sale price of vendor trash, yay!), making it actually reasonable to build a set to some degree and not feel like your gold is worthless.- Big bosses. If you fight a dragon, you know bloody well you're fighting a dragon because it tends to not exactly fit on the screen. There's things like "don't stand in the fire" on bosses as well, stuff that needs to be dodged and so on. As in things that you didn't actually see until much later games for the most part. Sacred's not quite as great as a modern game, but compared to anything else from it's timeframe, it was quite a few years ahead of it's time in this regard.Overall, it's dated. Sacred has low graphics, major technological problems, and some real massive flaws to it... but compared to other games of it's time, I'd honestly recommend it and say it's quite a lot better than it had any real right of being. It's enjoyable for awhile, and worth a good $5 or so. As of the moment of this review, it's on for $2.49, and for the single player game, I'd say it's well worth the cost. It probably won't be a regretable purchase, as it's really not that bad and does a lot of good things that even many of the modern diabloesque games fail to live up to.If you ever want to go down a trip on nostalgia lane and play diablo 1 for some reason (I get that every few years myself =P ) I'd honestly recommend playing Sacred for your binge this time around. It's the better game of the two in large part, and has some really attractive features to it. It has some nuisances as well, but hey, it's old, give it a break. NO! NOT THE HIP! NOT THE HIP!

Sacred Gold reunites all the expansions into one single release. However, doesn’t fix the previous issues or adds any improvement.It’s still a great and huge RPG, where the player hacks and slashes across hundreds of enemies, with tremendous looting and exploration to do!Originally released back in 2004, Sacred is completely 2D, except for the main hero, which shows itself 3D. The world itself looks very 3 dimensional, with beautiful areas, worthy of today’s most prestigious indie projects. Either you traverse the vast green plains, the deep dark forests, or the southern desert, you’ll be astonished by how beautiful Sacred looks.This enchantment easily gets you frustrated, as there are countless enemies across all the areas, in fact, there are just too many. For looting purposes, thus may sound like a dream come true, but ruins exploration as the player has to fight every single time!Ascaron tried their best with such huge project, however, they failed miserable by locking the resolution at 1024x768. Surely the standard back in the day, but today, it feels really bad.Thankfully, resolutions and frame rate can be improved by third party software like dgVoodoo2 that fixes and unlocks modern hardware usage.Sacred Gold is huge and for those who like to emerge themselves within a deep lore, full of quests and areas to explore, secrets to unveil and monsters to conquer, it’s highly recommended. Posted: November 12, 2016
												I've been quite a fan of this game ever since it released in Spain, around 2004 or so. It's been 12 f#cking years, and somehow this game still stands somewhat high between other games of it's kind. But you know, all games have bad stuff on them, and that's where I will start the review, then move up to the best stuff you should know about it before making your purchase.First and foremost, the game hasn't aged that well. Granted, it could work way worse, but you should totally expect the game to crash a few times, get stuck and not let you use the task manager to shut it down and stay on a low resolution. Infact, it seems to have issues with the videos, so you might have to disable them to even play... And that means missing on some parts of the story as well. It should also be said that the game has no Steam Overlay support.Second, it has some weird difficulty spikes. The game ain't really too difficult (and if you go with Bronze difficulty you'll rarelly even die), but there are a few parts that seem weird, mainly dragons. You're fighting the damn thing and suddenly it uses a fire-breathing attack and your hp, no matter how tanky you are, will explode. And almost without warning! There aren't much more enemies that are difficult on the game besides them, however then come things that are too easy, the final boss being the biggest example. It's quite the anticlimax when he barely does damage and you whoop his♥♥♥♥♥without effort. There's also enemies that deal poison as their main source of damage: poison is crap. Barely hurts, it's main effect seems to be slowing you down. That's quite dissapointing, however it also seems that using antidotes doesn't always even fix poison, which seems like a bug to me.Lastly, the graphics, while neat (specially for it's time), they have issues. The world is mainly a 2D gigantic landscape with semi-2D buildings and lots of 3D characters. The problem comes when buildings and the landscape get in between everything: buildings not letting you see enemies, hills hiding the way you're supposed to be going, objects that seem to be blocking a tight road but it's actually the way you should be going and it ain't blocked at all, it gets confusing a lot of times.Lastly, and mainly a minor problem, the English voices. They're a mix bag. The main characters actually do have a good voicecast, specially the Dwarf who's my favorite of them all. Then come enemies like goblins and orcs, which talk on their own language AS THEY SHOULD, instead of sh#ttified English, a really nice touch. Then, at the bottom of the barrel come enemies like the Sakkara Priests. The male ones sound okay but a bit forced, yelling each line at the top of their lungs, then come the female ones which SCREAM every line in the most stupidly hilarious accents possible and even keep screaming the most dumb death screams you'll hear in your life as they are decapitated with a damn hammer. I'd say 10% of the voices in the game are bad, only a 10%, but that 10% might even be a nice case of so bad it's actually good.That being said, what does the game do for itself? Have you played Diablo 1 or 2? It's similar, but in a MMO-sized world. Just think of World of Warcraft in 2D and singleplayer and you'll get the idea.The gameplay is enjoyable. There are 8 characters to choose (6 from the base game and 2 from the expansion included in the Steam edition) and they all feel quite different, with their own good and bad parts (although I've always felt the Dwarf was way more powerful and had a dumb negative part, not being able to ride horses). There's an insane amount of loot out there to get (and there are items which are only usable by certain characters) and each character has a good selection of skills you can use. It's fun, as you can just play whoever you feel like, and if you don't like it, just change your playstyle.The map itself should also get a mention as it's actually quite f#cking big for it's time and coming from a not-so-well-known developer team. There's plenty of different areas to explore, all of them with their own kind of enemies and obstacles, towns and different crap. And something that you don't see often is actually getting to visit the towns of the monsters you keep killing, which I like and it's a good touch. Specially since the Devs took the time to add places to the map that you don't have to visit through the storyline, but have quests and other good stuff on them, making you want to deviate from the main quests and just see what you can find.The game also offers a New Game+ option; you can export your character and then start a new game with it, which is great! It adds more difficulty and replayability to an already long game.The main characters are also fully voice acted and will usually give their own opinion to whatever is happening, which is fun, specially when they decide to break the forth wall and talk to you directly. The game also has a few references to other games and media, something I do enjoy a lot.Lastly, the game does have multiplayer... Although good luck finding anybody to play it with. After 12 years the servers are predictably dead and although you can play using third party software with some friends, it might be too much effort when you could just play something else instead.Do I recommend Sacred? If you like Roleplaying games with big open worlds, yes. Totally. It's a fun game that lasts, with the expansion pack included, around 16 to 20 hours, depending on how well you do. There's tons of stuff to discover and fun to be had, and in a sale it's probably a safe purchase... Just expect some technical problems to stay in the way at first. I will also say in advance that Sacred 2 is a decent follow up to this game (although more oriented to consoles than PC) and that Sacred 3 is a horrible follow up. You see, Sacred went the same way Dungeon Siege did: the first one is usually taken as the best, although it played it safe. The second one is a decent sequel with good aditions and other stuff that shouldn't be there. The third game however barely even looks like the rest and it's hated for it. If you ever look into this franchise, please stay with the first one, maybe just peek into the second one for curiosity. Ignore the third one, you'll be grateful.TL;DR Edition: Good open world RPG that's quite long but does have both technical difficulties and some difficulty issues. However it's quite enjoyable to people who can overlook it's age and how bad it works with a modern computer. On a sale, it's a safe purchase, although ignore it's sequels completely.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Sacred Gold is immersive and fun to play.  Atmospheric sound effects and voice acting are good.  The graphics are sufficiently detailed not to look dated.  Quests are non-linear, but some quest hubs will require backtracking to grind the odd extra level or two.  There are a good variety of characters to choose from.  Some weapons and armour are class specific.  Certain weapons and armour can be crafted, enhanced or customized.  The skill tree is interesting and offers many specialization choices while forcing trade-off decisions.  The map is a lot larger than it appears to be at first glance, which should become evident some hours into the game.  Mobs and bosses have good AI and will sometimes flee when injured.  Often pursuing a fleeing imp draws you into line of sight of additional mobs.  Overall the game is enjoyable and can keep a player engrossed for many hours.  Challenge and difficulty scale moderately so that one's character never feels insanely over-powered or unfairly overwhelmed.  Sacred is one of the games that slipped under the radar because Diablo 2 was the de-facto standard in the genre.  This game is really good and it is a pity so many players never noticed it.

Sacred: Gold  Field Rating Review   Graphics 4 Sacred hasn't aged very well, especially when you realize you can't run the game at full resolution on your monitor. There's a lot of optimizing issues the game has currently, so you'll run into random lag spikes that last a moment, particularly when running full screen. However, when it came out, the graphics were wonderful, and the animations very satisfying (the spell animations still are satisfying, just dated). So, with the age of this game in mind, I was a little more lenient.   Gameplay 9 Sacred is a classic hack-and-slash, and you will enjoy every darn minute of it. With a huge open world to explore, you can sink hours and hours into exploring every nook and cranny. While not being randomly generated, as several games in this genre now are, you will still find yourself exploring everywhere you can, time and time again. With 7 different classes to choose from, each with a unique playstyle, you won't get tired of booting this one up over and over.   Story 5 The story eeks by just enough to drive the game forward, but other than that, you won't find yourself caring that much. However, keep in mind this game has a lot of tongue-in-cheek humor, and treats its story as such. Thus, I give this on an even middle ground.   Multiplayer 7 Fantastic multiplayer, if you can get it to work. This would be a 10 if the darn thing worked well. Given the age of Sacred, it is a royal nightmare to get this one working correctly. But if you can manage to join a game together, you are in for one of the best times you've had gaming. (Due to the difficulty of joining multiplayer together, I have not included it in the overall score)   Replayability 8 With 7 classes, come 7 different playstyles, and a world large enough that you can just keep on going. I've owned this game since it came out, and I still find myself coming back to it over and over.I would come back even more if the multiplayer worked properly.   Overall 7.5/10 A long time favorite of mine, Sacred stands in a class of its own. I have plenty of fond memories playing this game with my Father and family over Christmas breaks. A lot of hack and slashers now and day are called Diablo-clones, but calling Sacred such a thing would do it a great injustice. With an expansive, sprawling world that puts Diablo to shame, and much more riveting gameplay, Sacred is not a game to be missed on any count. The multiplayer is outstanding and incredibly fun as you and your friends grow and battle in the world around you, saving it from the dark forces that are at play. 												Overview and talking about the experience of the game so far: What can I say about a 12 year old game? I mean i'm 13 myself. Being a 12 year old game the game is unfortunately not the prettiest to look at aswell as having many bugs in the game with some quests. If you can overcome that you have an amazing game especially if you like exploring. Just by exploring random places instead of doing the story missions I'm still on the first act and I'm way overleveled for the normal areas. Even if you are overleveled there are still challenging enemies if you explore enough , they are dragons , the first time I encountered one in the desert as part of a quest I just went up to it and died....... then I walked back trying to use a bow as a meele character and died again. After leveling up a bit I came back to that dragon using my vampiress and I still foolishly ran into the dragon but this time I beat it by using her teleport ability. It was awesome and certainly a step up of difficulty even with some legendary items.The bad parts: Some parts of the game are badly optimised if you explore in the wrong places , you walk through a path that's lower than you by 5 levels for like 2 minutes then walk past a bridge and you find enemies 3 levels higher than you which really is annoying finding useless areas that you haven't explored. Another annoying thing is that some quests are buggy and won't finish ( I had problems with 'The Painter' and that quest about the blacksmith early game.). The controls of the game will annoy people when they start the game as it is mostly controlled with the mouse as well as some keys like space to use a healing potion which can't be changed in the options. The great parts: Loot in the game is amazing. I've had 4 different legendaries equipt in 4 slots that were for 4 different things with some focused on damage and some focused on defence. The loot is very complex and you can't just look at the damage or defence stat to just determine if it's better you need to check all parts resistances , magic damage , amount of slots. From the vampiress alone you can see a huge variety of skills from summoning the undead bats and wolfs to turning corpses into your own vampire slaves to mind controlling people and teleporting away.Conclusion: Basically it's just a complex game , it may be considered boring and slow to people who just look for action but for those willing to explore and be patient you will become this power house which is just the most fun thing ever. Dragons become just mini bosses you slay for some of the best loot causing you to get even more powerful. 9/10 from me but it is certainly not for those action seekers.DISCLAIMER ABOUT GAME BEING BROKEN: If you buy this game before activation you will need to get into the games files: 1.  This game is outdated, but still super cool! TL/DR:Buy this game if you look for a "fresh" version of the H&S genre, even though it has many flaws, it is still very exciting and fun.So i picked this game up since it was on sale. I had it on CD many years ago but never installed it. Sacred is very unforgiving when it comes to fighting, first time i played the game i died around 10 times by the first group of enemies. In other famous H&S games like diablo and grim dawn enemies tend to be more "careful" and not stay to close to settlements, villages etc.In Sacred they can be in the outskirts of the city. I was lost for 2 hours because i tried a different road, but it was exciting, since the map is filled with cities, caves and biomes to be explored. The map is also made by devs. A lot of loot to choose from, but not an overwhelming amountYou can ride a horseFighting enemies is difficult, especially in the beginning. You are in charge of how you want your character to become.  It tries, but falls shortIf you liked Diablo, DIablo 2, Baldur's Gate and Neverwinter Nights the developers were certainly hoping you'd like this game as well. Sadly, much like me dreams of winning the lottery, those hopes will never be realized. The game is just too un polished, the combat hardly carries the satisfying feel of DIablo, DIablo 2 or Torchlight and it lacks the strategic elements of say Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's gate.. The look and feel of the game in general has a weird paradox. The modeling is certainly top notch but the animation is laughable. Just watching your character run is enough to give a laugh.Maybe it improves with the later installments but after seeing this.. I'm not particularly motivated to try.Not to say it is  a bad game really. There are certainly worse and there was genuine effort put in but I think this is one occasion where the attempt at more 'realistic' aesthetics needlessly hobbled the overall game. A more stylized version may have lent itself to more dynamic and fluid animation which would have made the combat a bit more satisfying.So count this as a borderline review.

												A cheap, shallow, tedious, malformed Diablo Clone (going so far as to directly rip off Diablo's Item classification colors) that fails to live up to the notion in every way. Sacred is a slow and bloated mess with, even for the time, terrible graphics, horrible animations, and a clunky interface. I'm certain the actors who voiced the characters hurt themselves in the process because they were clearly acting AS HARD AS THEY POSSIBLY COULD. Maybe this was supposed to be funny or endearing, but it's nothing more than another turn off among a litany of problems.There is NO sense of progression as it's saddled with the obscene habit of leveling everything always and forever to the point of your character, the bestiary is lame, uninspired, and copy-pasted to the umteenth exponent, you can never get ahead of the curve no matter how much time you waste grinding, leveling up barely gives you anything to work with, and this has perhaps the worst item system I've ever tried to put up with.Endless streams of items labeled "crappy broken crap of crappyness", half of which you arbitrarily can't use because of idiotic class restrictions. Items which should stack don't, and again, this is not excusable by the game's age, and there's no clear rhyme, reason, or again, progression behind any of it. This is an endless, grindy treadmill without any reward or satisfaction, plagued by terrible systems, low quality design, and a bad interface. This game is awful, and I pity the soul who pays full price for it.

Still a game worth buying for 9.99 or less for sure. To be fair it is probably better to wait for a super sale and buy all the games at a discount price. It is a game that will live on for people who like this genre. The gameplay music is well done and the tutorial help is easy to understand. 												This game is a massive waste of time. I don't care who tells me what. As soon as you start roaming it's all the same, literally thousands of enemies per area that spawn randomly around you with a few scattered safe zones and mostly worthless quests. If you're a massive fan of grinding the same thing with different enemies over and over again then you could spend years on this game. Unfortunately for those of us that need something else besides 5 minutes worth of bundles quests when we discover a new area, the grinding gets really old really fast. Has an exceptionally clunky system where movement, most activations, and attacking are done with the mouse and can be done interchangeably, mostly done by accident. There are quests that allow you to start within the quests (starting at point B) and when it tells you to return to the quest-giver you've never been to (point A) the quest bugs out and you can't complete them. Then there's also the whole troubleshooting problem I had where I had to navigate through the steam folders to actually start playing the game and fix the crashes. I get it, this is an older game, but I've played plenty from this time that were just better executed. Other than large bosses that are absurdly overpowered, you can stand in a hoard of 15 enemies and be relatively fine. As much as I enjoy mindlessly click-holding on several thousand 1-3 hit killed enemies to come across something that can either last 15 seconds in combat, or swipe me away with ease. If you honestly want a grindfest it should come with some level of a reward, not more grindfesting and in the plethora of items you find picking up something decent every now and again.
